Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Development of Ultrasensitive, Superfast, and Microliter-Volume Differential Scanning Nanocalorimeter for Direct Characterization of Biomolecular Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Award Abstract: Development of Ultrasensitive, Superfast, and Microliter-Volume Differential Scanning Nanocalorimeter for Direct Characterization of Biomolecular Interactions

The proposed differential scanning nanocalorimeter will significantly reduce the sample volume and shorten the measurement time of molecular phenomena, and provide a powerful tool for comprehensive high-content thermodynamics studies, in the study of membrane proteins and in the early stage of drug discovery. This multidisciplinary research will provide excellent opportunities to young scientists and engineers, especially women and underrepresented minorities. Interaction with national laboratories and industry at different ends of the application spectrum will enable accelerated implementation of the developed knowledge.

All biological phenomena depend on molecular interactions, which is either intermolecular, as with ligand binding to a protein, or intramolecular, as with protein folding. As a label-free and immobilization-free method, modern calorimetry instrumentation is the gold standard for directly characterizing the thermodynamic profiles of molecular interactions, including Gibbs free energy, enthalpy, entropy, specific heat, and stoichiometry, providing valuable information for investigating biolomolecular mechanisms and drug design, information that cannot be obtained from structural or computational methods alone. However, the current state-of-the-art calorimeters require large-volume, high-concentration proteins and need very long measurement times, which limits their utility for biological studies. The objective of this award is to develop an innovative MEMS-based differential scanning nanocalorimeter and array to reduce the consumption of biological macromolecules from milliliters to micro liters, and to decrease the measurement time from hours to minutes, and thus enable direct, precise, and rapid detection of biomolecular interactions. To achieve this goal, four specific tasks are planned, including 1) designing and fabricating ultrasensitive low-noise sensors, 2) minimizing the parasitic heat loss of the nanocalorimeter, 3) designing and integrating low-noise electronics and feedback controller, and 4) testing and applying this technology to membrane protein study and pharmaceutical screening.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Description

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) is one of the few techniques that allow direct determination of enthalpy values for binding reactions and conformational transitions in biomolecules. It provides the thermodynamics information of the biomolecules which consists of Gibbs free energy, enthalpy and entropy in a straightforward manner that enables deep understanding of the structure function relationship in biomolecules such as the folding/unfolding of protein and DNA, ligand bindings, etc.

The objective of this project is to develop an innovative nano differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) instrument using standard MEMS techniques to reduce the consumption of biological macromolecules from milliliters to micro liters and to decrease the measurement time from hours to minutes, and thus enable direct and rapid detection of biomolecular interaction. Application of the instrument in biological studies includes early drug discovery and membrane proteins.

 

Intellectual Merit

 (1) The proposed nano DSC can provide a direct understanding of the denaturation process of protein sample at micro liter volume in a high throughput manner. The volume consumption is less than 1 microliter and the whole measurement time is less than 10 min. The sensitivity and throughput is the better than previous results. It enables comprehensive high-content thermodynamics study in the early stage of drug discovery and formulation. (2) It also enables direct, precise, and rapid evaluation of the folding and unfolding of the large biomolecules like proteins, DNAs, and enzymes without labeling or immobilization. It can also be used to detect the aggregation phenomena in bio-reaction process. (3)The proposed research is multi-disciplinary, incorporating areas of biological, chemical, mechanical, materials, electronics, control, and microfabrication. It will create new knowledge in the interdisciplinary area, such as the synthesis of ultrasensitive temperature sensors.

 

 

Broader Impacts

The proposed research has broad impacts on society, education, industry, and other scientific disciplines. (1) The throughput of the proposed nano DSC is 10 to 100 times higher than the commercial DSC and the sample consumption is more than 10 times smaller. Once commercialized, it will directly save large amount of pharmaceutical R&D expenditure by providing high-quality leads and reducing the high-cost clinical trials, which is currently $50-$140M per drug. (2) The nano DSC developed in the project are also very useful in other non-biological scientific areas like nano materials and crystal structures. (3) In this project, we collaborated with Brookhaven National Lab and AbbVie Inc. The interaction with a national lab and industry at different ends of the application spectrum enable accelerated implementation of the developed knowledge.

 

Outcomes

The outcomes are in the following:

  1. Flexible polyimide substrate was fabricated by release layer from the silicon wafer. The adhesion between the polymer layer and silicon layer is made moderate; it is adhesive enough to bond the two together even if subject to various MEMS fabricating process, and at the same time, the adhesion is small enough to separate the two layer without causing stresses, which might potentially induce the failure of the devices (Fig.1). 
  2. A highly sensitive thermistor material was developed for the sensing. Vanadium oxide (VOx) as a new semiconductor material has a high temperature coefficient of resistivity with relatively low resistivity. The fabrication of the vanadium oxide thin film could be accomplished by DC sputtering with oxidization. The temperature coefficient could reach to -2.8%/oC (Fig.2). 
  3. A novel double-spiral micro heater was designed to achieve uniform temperature heating for the nano DSC calibration. By manually change the width of the trace, the heating power distribution can be controlled to achieve high temperature uniformity (Fig. 3).
  4. The novel double layer microfluidic chamber was integrated into the system to deliver the bio-samples to the heating area while minimize the liquid sample evaporation and maximize the thermal isolation. The first layer is the Flexdym (a soft thermal plastic elastomer) based microchamber.  Delicate Flexdym microfluidic chamber was first designed and fabricated. SU 8 100 was used to fabricate the master pattern. Second, the second PDMS chamber was fabricated using the same SU 8 master pattern. The two layers were first bonded together and then bonded with the calorimeter device using hot-press method (Fig. 4).
  5. A heating stage and a temperature enclosure to perform the temperature scanning with high reliability, linearity and high scanning rate (45oC/min) was designed and fabricated. The temperature uniformity of the heating stage was improved and characterized using the FLIR A655sc camera.
  6. Characterization of the device was carried out to measure the sensitivity and response time. The response time was obtained to be 5.9 s with 0.63L of sample consumption. The thermal conductance was reduced to 1375W/K to achieve highly thermal insulated environment. The sensitivity of the device could reach 6.1mV/mW. Biological sample testing was performed with the calorimeter. We have tested lysozyme samples with the concentration of 10mg/mL, and the results was close to the published results in the literature. (Fig. 6)
